title: 1 Timothy Chapter 1 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Timothy chapter 1 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Timothy Chapter 1 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Timothy Chapter 1.

questions.question: Who is the author of the letter in 1 Timothy 1?
questions.correctAnswer: Paul
questions.explanation: The letter is written by Paul, an apostle of Jesus Christ, as stated in 1 Timothy 1:1.

questions.question: To whom is the letter in 1 Timothy 1 addressed?
questions.correctAnswer: Timothy
questions.explanation: Paul addresses Timothy, calling him his own son in the faith, as seen in 1 Timothy 1:2.

questions.question: Where did Paul instruct Timothy to remain according to 1 Timothy 1?
questions.correctAnswer: Ephesus
questions.explanation: Paul asked Timothy to stay in Ephesus to charge some not to teach other doctrines (1 Timothy 1:3).

questions.question: What does Paul warn Timothy not to give heed to?
questions.correctAnswer: Fables and endless genealogies
questions.explanation: Paul warns against fables and endless genealogies that cause questions rather than godly edifying (1 Timothy 1:4).

questions.question: According to 1 Timothy 1:5, what is the end of the commandment?
options: Charity out of a pure heart
questions.correctAnswer: Charity out of a pure heart
questions.explanation: The end of the commandment is charity (love) out of a pure heart, good conscience, and unfeigned faith (1 Timothy 1:5).

questions.question: Who does Paul say the law is made for?
questions.correctAnswer: The lawless and disobedient
questions.explanation: Paul explains the law is for the lawless and disobedient, not for the righteous (1 Timothy 1:9).

questions.question: Which of these is NOT mentioned as one the law is made for?
questions.correctAnswer: Pilgrims
questions.explanation: Pilgrims are not mentioned; the law is made for sinners such as murderers, whoremongers, and liars (1 Timothy 1:9-10).

questions.question: What reason does Paul give for his gratitude to Christ Jesus?
options: He counted Paul faithful and put him into ministry
questions.correctAnswer: He counted Paul faithful and put him into ministry
questions.explanation: Paul thanks Christ because He counted him faithful and entrusted him with ministry (1 Timothy 1:12).

questions.question: What was Paul before he obtained mercy?
questions.correctAnswer: A blasphemer and persecutor
questions.explanation: Paul describes himself as a blasphemer, persecutor, and injurious before receiving mercy (1 Timothy 1:13).

questions.question: What is described as exceeding abundant with faith and love in Christ Jesus?
questions.correctAnswer: The grace of our Lord
questions.explanation: Paul states the grace of our Lord was exceeding abundant with faith and love which is in Christ Jesus (1 Timothy 1:14).

questions.question: What is the faithful saying mentioned in 1 Timothy 1:15?
options: Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners
questions.correctAnswer: Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners
questions.explanation: The faithful saying is that Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners (1 Timothy 1:15).

questions.question: True or False: Paul says he is the chief of sinners.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Paul calls himself the chief of sinners in 1 Timothy 1:15.

questions.question: True or False: Paul was delivered unto Satan so that he might learn not to blaspheme.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Paul did not receive this punishment; Hymenaeus and Alexander were delivered unto Satan to learn not to blaspheme (1 Timothy 1:20).

questions.question: True or False: The King eternal is described as immortal and invisible.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: In 1 Timothy 1:17, God is described as the King eternal, immortal, and invisible.

questions.question: Complete this verse from 1 Timothy 1:18: 'This charge I commit unto thee, son Timothy, according to the __________ which went before on thee.'
questions.correctAnswer: prophecies
questions.explanation: The verse states the charge is committed according to the prophecies which went before on Timothy (1 Timothy 1:18).

medium.title: 1 Timothy Chapter 1 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Timothy Chapter 1 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does 1 Timothy 1 teach us about the importance of sound doctrine in the church?
options: We should avoid fables and endless genealogies that promote questions rather than faith
We should accept all teachings as valid to maintain peace
We should focus only on traditions and ignore scriptures
We should not challenge any teaching to avoid conflict
questions.correctAnswer: We should avoid fables and endless genealogies that promote questions rather than faith
questions.explanation: 1 Timothy 1:3-4 instructs Timothy to charge certain people not to teach other doctrines or give heed to fables and endless genealogies which cause questions rather than godly edifying in faith.

questions.question: A fellow believer struggles with confusion over many teachings. Based on 1 Timothy 1, what biblical truth would you share?
options: The goal of the commandment is love from a pure heart, good conscience, and sincere faith
It is best to follow the most popular teacher
Faith is not important as long as you are sincere
Teachings should be based on personal opinions
questions.correctAnswer: The goal of the commandment is love from a pure heart, good conscience, and sincere faith
questions.explanation: 1 Timothy 1:5 explains that the end goal of the commandment is love that flows from a pure heart, a good conscience, and genuine faith, which can guide believers through confusing teachings.

questions.question: What warning does Paul give about those desiring to be teachers of the law?
options: They do not understand what they say or affirm
They are always faithful and wise
They should be honored above others
questions.correctAnswer: They do not understand what they say or affirm
questions.explanation: 1 Timothy 1:7 states that some desire to be teachers of the law but do not understand what they say or whereof they affirm, warning against false teachers lacking true knowledge.

questions.question: How does this passage describe the lawful use of the law?
options: The law is good if used lawfully
The law is always burdensome and evil
The law applies only to the righteous
The law is obsolete and should be ignored
questions.correctAnswer: The law is good if used lawfully
questions.explanation: 1 Timothy 1:8 acknowledges that the law is good if a person uses it in a lawful manner, emphasizing proper understanding and application of God's commands.

questions.question: Based on 1 Timothy 1, what types of people is the law intended to address?
options: Lawless, disobedient, ungodly, sinners, and those contrary to sound doctrine
Those who are perfect and sinless
The law has no specific target group
questions.correctAnswer: Lawless, disobedient, ungodly, sinners, and those contrary to sound doctrine
questions.explanation: 1 Timothy 1:9-10 lists various types of lawbreakers and sinners for whom the law was made, showing its purpose to restrain and correct wrongdoing.

questions.question: What reason does Paul give for thanking Christ Jesus our Lord in his ministry?
options: Because Christ counted him faithful and enabled him for ministry
Because he was perfect and without sin
Because he was wealthy and influential
Because he was popular among believers
questions.correctAnswer: Because Christ counted him faithful and enabled him for ministry
questions.explanation: 1 Timothy 1:12 states Paul thanks Christ Jesus for counting him faithful and enabling him to serve in the ministry despite his past.

questions.question: How does 1 Timothy 1 illustrate the power of mercy and grace in Christian living?
options: Paul was a blasphemer and persecutor but obtained mercy because of ignorance and unbelief
Grace is only for those without sin
Mercy is given only to the perfect
Grace is not important in salvation
questions.correctAnswer: Paul was a blasphemer and persecutor but obtained mercy because of ignorance and unbelief
questions.explanation: 1 Timothy 1:13-14 explains that Paul’s past as a blasphemer and persecutor was met with mercy and abundant grace, showing God’s forgiveness for sinners.

questions.question: What is described as a faithful saying worthy of all acceptance in 1 Timothy 1?
options: Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners, of whom Paul is chief
questions.correctAnswer: Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners, of whom Paul is chief
questions.explanation: 1 Timothy 1:15 states that it is a trustworthy saying that Christ came to save sinners, highlighting the central message of the gospel.

questions.question: How does Paul describe the purpose of his receiving mercy in 1 Timothy 1?
options: So that Jesus Christ might show all longsuffering as a pattern to future believers
So that he could be proud of his past
questions.correctAnswer: So that Jesus Christ might show all longsuffering as a pattern to future believers
questions.explanation: 1 Timothy 1:16 explains that Paul's mercy was granted to demonstrate Christ’s patience as an example for others who would believe and receive eternal life.

questions.question: What attributes of God does Paul praise in 1 Timothy 1?
options: King eternal, immortal, invisible, the only wise God
A God who changes according to circumstance
A God limited by time and space
A God who is silent and distant
questions.correctAnswer: King eternal, immortal, invisible, the only wise God
questions.explanation: 1 Timothy 1:17 extols God as eternal, immortal, invisible, and wise, worthy of honor and glory forever.

questions.question: A believer feels discouraged in their spiritual battle. What encouragement does 1 Timothy 1 offer about fighting the good fight of faith?
options: Timothy is charged to wage a good warfare holding faith and a good conscience
Faith is unimportant in spiritual battles
The fight is hopeless and should be avoided
Conscience has no role in spiritual warfare
questions.correctAnswer: Timothy is charged to wage a good warfare holding faith and a good conscience
questions.explanation: 1 Timothy 1:18-19 encourages believers to hold faith and a good conscience as they engage in the spiritual struggle, emphasizing perseverance and integrity.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Timothy 1, some have made shipwreck of their faith by rejecting a good conscience.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Timothy 1:19 explains that some have rejected faith and a good conscience, causing them to shipwreck their faith, highlighting the importance of conscience in Christian living.

questions.question: True or False: Hymenaeus and Alexander were commended by Paul for their faithful teaching in 1 Timothy 1.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Timothy 1:20 shows Paul delivered Hymenaeus and Alexander to Satan so they might learn not to blaspheme, indicating their unfaithfulness.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Paul calls Timothy his own son in the ______.
questions.correctAnswer: faith
questions.explanation: 1 Timothy 1:2 refers to Timothy as Paul's own son in the faith, indicating a spiritual father-son relationship based on shared belief.

questions.question: How should believers respond to the charge Timothy received according to 1 Timothy 1?
options: By holding on to faith and a good conscience to wage a good warfare
By ignoring prophecies and focusing on personal desires
By relying solely on human wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: By holding on to faith and a good conscience to wage a good warfare
questions.explanation: 1 Timothy 1:18-19 instructs Timothy to engage in spiritual warfare holding faith and a good conscience, which believers should emulate for spiritual perseverance.

hard.title: 1 Timothy Chapter 1 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Timothy Chapter 1.

questions.question: According to 1 Timothy 1:1, Paul identifies himself as an apostle by the commandment of whom?
options: God our Saviour and Lord Jesus Christ
questions.correctAnswer: God our Saviour and Lord Jesus Christ
questions.explanation: Paul explicitly states he is an apostle by commandment of God our Saviour and Lord Jesus Christ, indicating divine authority (1 Timothy 1:1).

questions.question: In 1 Timothy 1:3-4, Paul charges Timothy to prevent teaching what kinds of doctrines?
questions.correctAnswer: Fables and endless genealogies
questions.explanation: Paul instructs Timothy to charge some not to teach fables and endless genealogies, which cause disputes rather than godly edification (1 Timothy 1:3-4).

questions.question: What is described as the 'end of the commandment' in 1 Timothy 1:5?
options: Charity out of a pure heart, and of a good conscience, and of faith unfeigned
questions.correctAnswer: Charity out of a pure heart, and of a good conscience, and of faith unfeigned
questions.explanation: The verse highlights that the ultimate purpose of the commandment is love (charity) from a pure heart, good conscience, and genuine faith (1 Timothy 1:5).

questions.question: What does Paul say about those desiring to be teachers of the law in 1 Timothy 1:7?
options: They understand neither what they say nor whereof they affirm
They are the pillars of the church
They are well versed in the Scriptures
questions.correctAnswer: They understand neither what they say nor whereof they affirm
questions.explanation: Paul criticizes certain individuals who want to be teachers but lack true understanding of their teaching (1 Timothy 1:7).

questions.question: How does 1 Timothy 1:8 describe the Law in relation to a man who uses it properly?
options: The law is good if a man uses it lawfully
The law is obsolete for Christians
The law is only for priests
The law is harsh and condemning
questions.correctAnswer: The law is good if a man uses it lawfully
questions.explanation: Paul affirms the goodness of the law when it is used lawfully, indicating proper understanding and application (1 Timothy 1:8).

questions.question: According to 1 Timothy 1:9-10, for whom was the law made?
options: The lawless and disobedient, ungodly and sinners, unholy and profane
All who believe in Jesus Christ
questions.correctAnswer: The lawless and disobedient, ungodly and sinners, unholy and profane
questions.explanation: Paul explains the law is designed for those who violate it, listing various sinners and those contrary to sound doctrine (1 Timothy 1:9-10).

questions.question: What gospel does Paul refer to as 'glorious' and 'committed to my trust' in 1 Timothy 1:11?
options: The glorious gospel of the blessed God
The gospel of the kingdom of Israel
The gospel of the law of Moses
questions.correctAnswer: The glorious gospel of the blessed God
questions.explanation: Paul calls the gospel he preaches the glorious gospel of the blessed God, entrusted to him for proclamation (1 Timothy 1:11).

questions.question: What transformation does Paul describe about himself in 1 Timothy 1:13?
options: He was a blasphemer, persecutor, and injurious, but obtained mercy
He was a faithful teacher from youth
He was a king before becoming an apostle
He was a Pharisee who never sinned
questions.correctAnswer: He was a blasphemer, persecutor, and injurious, but obtained mercy
questions.explanation: Paul admits his past as a blasphemer and persecutor, yet he received mercy because he acted ignorantly in unbelief (1 Timothy 1:13).

questions.question: According to 1 Timothy 1:15, what is 'a faithful saying' worthy of all acceptation?
options: Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners
The law must be followed to be saved
Only the righteous will see God
questions.correctAnswer: Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners
questions.explanation: Paul states this saying as trustworthy: Jesus came to save sinners, of whom Paul considers himself chief (1 Timothy 1:15).

questions.question: What purpose does Paul give for his receiving mercy in 1 Timothy 1:16?
options: To show forth all longsuffering as a pattern to future believers
To be an example of perfect obedience
questions.correctAnswer: To show forth all longsuffering as a pattern to future believers
questions.explanation: Paul explains mercy was given so Jesus Christ might demonstrate patience through him as a pattern for believers to inherit eternal life (1 Timothy 1:16).

questions.question: How does 1 Timothy 1:17 describe God?
options: King eternal, immortal, invisible, the only wise God
Creator of the heavens and the earth
questions.correctAnswer: King eternal, immortal, invisible, the only wise God
questions.explanation: The verse praises God as eternal, immortal, invisible, and the only wise God deserving honor and glory (1 Timothy 1:17).

questions.question: What charge does Paul commit to Timothy in 1 Timothy 1:18?
options: To war a good warfare according to prophecies
To build the church in Ephesus
To preach to the Gentiles exclusively
questions.correctAnswer: To war a good warfare according to prophecies
questions.explanation: Paul charges Timothy to fight the good fight of faith as foretold by prophecies concerning him (1 Timothy 1:18).

questions.question: According to 1 Timothy 1:19, what have some made shipwreck concerning faith?
questions.correctAnswer: Faith and a good conscience
questions.explanation: Paul notes that some have rejected faith and a good conscience, resulting in spiritual shipwreck (1 Timothy 1:19).

questions.question: Who are the two individuals mentioned in 1 Timothy 1:20 that were delivered unto Satan to learn not to blaspheme?
questions.correctAnswer: Hymenaeus and Alexander
questions.explanation: Paul specifically names Hymenaeus and Alexander as those handed over to Satan to correct their blasphemy (1 Timothy 1:20).

questions.question: True or False: In 1 Timothy 1:14, Paul describes the grace of the Lord as exceeding abundant with faith and love in Christ Jesus.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Paul affirms that the grace of the Lord was exceedingly abundant with faith and love in Christ Jesus (1 Timothy 1:14).

theological.title: 1 Timothy Chapter 1 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Timothy Chapter 1 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to 1 Timothy 1:1, by whose commandment does Paul claim his apostleship?
options: God our Saviour and Lord Jesus Christ
questions.correctAnswer: God our Saviour and Lord Jesus Christ
questions.explanation: Paul states in 1 Timothy 1:1 that he is an apostle by the commandment of God our Saviour and Lord Jesus Christ, affirming divine authority for his ministry. This aligns with Acts 9:15 where Paul is chosen by God, and with Romans 1:1 where Paul calls himself an apostle appointed by Jesus Christ and God.

questions.question: In 1 Timothy 1:5, what is described as the 'end of the commandment'?
options: Charity out of a pure heart, and of a good conscience, and of faith unfeigned
questions.correctAnswer: Charity out of a pure heart, and of a good conscience, and of faith unfeigned
questions.explanation: 1 Timothy 1:5 teaches that the ultimate goal (end) of the commandment is love (charity) that springs from a pure heart, good conscience, and sincere faith. This reflects Jesus' summary of the law in Matthew 22:37-40 and the apostolic teaching on faith expressing itself through love (Galatians 5:6).

questions.question: What does Paul warn Timothy to avoid teaching in 1 Timothy 1:3-4?
options: Other doctrines, fables, and endless genealogies
The importance of faith and love
questions.correctAnswer: Other doctrines, fables, and endless genealogies
questions.explanation: Paul instructs Timothy in 1 Timothy 1:3-4 to charge certain people not to teach other doctrines, fables, and endless genealogies, which cause questions rather than edification. This echoes warnings against false teachers in Titus 1:14 and 2 Timothy 2:16.

questions.question: According to 1 Timothy 1:8-10, for whom was the law made?
options: The lawless, disobedient, ungodly, sinners, unholy, profane, murderers, fornicators, menstealers, liars, and perjurers
Righteous men who keep the law perfectly
All who believe in Jesus Christ
questions.correctAnswer: The lawless, disobedient, ungodly, sinners, unholy, profane, murderers, fornicators, menstealers, liars, and perjurers
questions.explanation: Paul explains in 1 Timothy 1:8-10 that the law is not meant for the righteous but for sinners and lawbreakers, listing specific types of offenses. This aligns with Romans 3:20 that the law exposes sin, and Galatians 3:19 that the law was given because of transgressions.

questions.question: What does Paul identify as the 'faithful saying' in 1 Timothy 1:15?
options: Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners
All must keep the law perfectly
questions.correctAnswer: Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners
questions.explanation: 1 Timothy 1:15 declares the trustworthy saying that Christ Jesus came to save sinners. This is central to Christian doctrine, as affirmed in Luke 19:10 where Jesus states his mission to seek and save the lost, and 1 John 4:14 which speaks of Christ as the Savior of the world.

questions.question: In 1 Timothy 1:12-14, how does Paul describe his past before receiving mercy?
options: A disciple of Jesus from the beginning
questions.correctAnswer: A blasphemer, persecutor, and injurious
questions.explanation: Paul admits in 1 Timothy 1:13 that he was formerly a blasphemer, persecutor, and injurious, but obtained mercy because he acted in ignorance and unbelief. This is consistent with Acts 9:1-6 and 1 Corinthians 15:9 where Paul recounts his former hostility toward the church.

questions.question: What does Paul say is the purpose of his receiving mercy in 1 Timothy 1:16?
options: That Jesus Christ might display all longsuffering as a pattern to believers
To prove that the law is unnecessary
questions.correctAnswer: That Jesus Christ might display all longsuffering as a pattern to believers
questions.explanation: Paul explains in 1 Timothy 1:16 that his mercy serves to show Christ's patience as an example for future believers. This ties to Romans 15:4 which states that endurance and encouragement come from Scripture, and 2 Timothy 2:2 about entrusting the gospel to faithful men.

questions.question: According to 1 Timothy 1:17, what attributes are ascribed to God?
options: King eternal, immortal, invisible, only wise God
A god of war and vengeance
A temporary ruler of the heavens
A created being with limited power
questions.correctAnswer: King eternal, immortal, invisible, only wise God
questions.explanation: Paul praises God in 1 Timothy 1:17 as eternal, immortal, invisible, and only wise, emphasizing divine transcendence and wisdom. This description parallels Exodus 15:18 where God is called King forever, and 1 Corinthians 2:6-7 about God’s wisdom.

questions.question: What charge does Paul give Timothy in 1 Timothy 1:18?
options: To war a good warfare according to prophecies
To abandon teaching and live quietly
To avoid conflict at all costs
questions.correctAnswer: To war a good warfare according to prophecies
questions.explanation: Paul instructs Timothy in 1 Timothy 1:18 to engage in spiritual warfare faithfully as foretold by prophecy. This reflects the apostolic call to perseverance and fight the good fight of faith (2 Timothy 4:7) and Ephesians 6:12-13 about spiritual warfare.

questions.question: What does Paul say about those who have 'put away' a good conscience in 1 Timothy 1:19?
options: They have made shipwreck concerning the faith
They have been rewarded by God
questions.correctAnswer: They have made shipwreck concerning the faith
questions.explanation: In 1 Timothy 1:19, Paul states that some who abandon faith and a good conscience have made shipwreck, i.e., destroyed their spiritual well-being. This aligns with Hebrews 6:4-6 warning against falling away and 2 Peter 2:20-22 about the dangers of apostasy.

questions.question: Who are the two individuals Paul says he delivered unto Satan in 1 Timothy 1:20, and why?
options: Hymenaeus and Alexander, that they may learn not to blaspheme
Peter and John, for denying Christ
questions.correctAnswer: Hymenaeus and Alexander, that they may learn not to blaspheme
questions.explanation: Paul names Hymenaeus and Alexander in 1 Timothy 1:20 as those handed over to Satan to teach them not to blaspheme. This disciplinary action aligns with the church’s responsibility to correct false teachers, consistent with Matthew 18:15-17 and 2 Timothy 2:17-18.

questions.question: According to 1 Timothy 1:7, why do some desire to be teachers of the law incorrectly?
options: Because they understand neither what they say nor whereof they affirm
Because they seek to help others grow in faith
questions.correctAnswer: Because they understand neither what they say nor whereof they affirm
questions.explanation: Paul criticizes in 1 Timothy 1:7 those who desire to be teachers of the law but lack true understanding. This reflects warnings in Jeremiah 23:31-32 against false prophets and in James 3:1 about the seriousness of teaching.

questions.question: What blessing does Paul invoke upon Timothy in 1 Timothy 1:2?
options: Grace, mercy, and peace from God the Father and Jesus Christ our Lord
questions.correctAnswer: Grace, mercy, and peace from God the Father and Jesus Christ our Lord
questions.explanation: In 1 Timothy 1:2, Paul blesses Timothy with grace, mercy, and peace from God and Jesus Christ, a common apostolic greeting found also in Romans 1:7 and Philippians 1:2, emphasizing God’s unmerited favor and spiritual wellbeing.

questions.question: How does 1 Timothy 1:14 describe the grace of the Lord?
options: Exceeding abundant with faith and love which is in Christ Jesus
questions.correctAnswer: Exceeding abundant with faith and love which is in Christ Jesus
questions.explanation: Paul describes the grace of the Lord in 1 Timothy 1:14 as exceedingly abundant, accompanied by faith and love in Christ Jesus. This corresponds to Ephesians 2:8-9 on grace through faith, and 2 Corinthians 9:14 on the generosity of God’s grace.

questions.question: What is the hope mentioned in 1 Timothy 1:1 in relation to Jesus Christ?
options: Lord Jesus Christ, which is our hope
questions.correctAnswer: Lord Jesus Christ, which is our hope
questions.explanation: Paul identifies Jesus Christ as the hope of believers in 1 Timothy 1:1, indicating the eschatological and salvific assurance found in Christ. This aligns with Titus 2:13 and 1 Peter 1:3 which highlight the living hope through the resurrection of Jesus.
